With technology companies like KenCall emerging in Africa, Thomas L. Friedman's key observation that something is stirring on the continent is right on point (''The Africa Connection,'' column, April 4).

Despite the perpetual tales of woe that dominate, two powerful forces are driving Africa forward in ways that few are willing to articulate. The first is technology, as exemplified by the explosion in mobile telephony that has turned Africa into the fastest-growing market in the world, at more than twice the international average growth in subscriber numbers.

The second is the rise of a youthful, confident, entrepreneurial and well-educated vanguard of Africans who are leading a total overhaul of the continent. With the analogy that it is best to hand a man a fishing rod and not filleted fish, it is imperative that discourse on Africa shift toward harnessing these positive forces that ultimately will be the dynamic impetus that propels it forward.
